title: 106_s768
content: The Act titled "Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000" establishes federal jurisdiction for criminal offenses committed by certain members of the Armed Forces and individuals employed by or accompanying the Armed Forces outside the United States. It includes provisions for arrest, delivery to foreign authorities, limitations on removal, initial proceedings, regulations, and definitions. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 establishes federal jurisdiction for criminal offenses committed by certain members of the Armed Forces outside the United States. Prosecution under this act is prohibited if a foreign government is already prosecuting the individual for the same offense, unless approved by the Attorney General or Deputy Attorney General. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 grants federal jurisdiction for criminal offenses committed by certain members of the Armed Forces outside the US. Courts-martial, military commissions, or other military tribunals retain concurrent jurisdiction for certain offenses. Prosecution under this act against a member of the Armed Forces subject to the Uniform Code of Military Justice requires specific conditions to be met. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 allows the Secretary of Defense to authorize law enforcement personnel to arrest individuals outside the US for violating specified sections. The arrested person must be handed over to US civilian authorities for judicial proceedings, unless charges have been brought under chapter 47 of title 10. Delivery to foreign authorities is subject to specific conditions. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 allows designated individuals to deliver suspects to foreign authorities if requested and authorized by treaty. The Secretary of Defense determines appropriate foreign officials. There are limitations on removal. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 allows designated individuals to deliver suspects to foreign authorities if authorized by treaty. Limitations on removal exist, with exceptions for detention hearings and pre-trial detention in the United States. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 allows designated individuals to deliver suspects to foreign authorities if authorized by treaty. Exceptions for removal include entitlement to a preliminary examination under the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, orders from a Federal magistrate judge, or a waiver by the Secretary of Defense for military necessity. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 allows designated individuals to deliver suspects to foreign authorities if authorized by treaty. Sec. 3265 covers initial proceedings, including exceptions for removal such as entitlement to a preliminary examination under the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2000 allows for the initial appearance of individuals charged with a violation under section 3261(a) to be conducted by a Federal magistrate judge. The judge must determine if there is probable cause to believe the offense was committed before proceeding. The Federal magistrate judge conducts the initial appearance of individuals charged under section 3261(a) and determines conditions of release before trial. Detention hearings can be conducted by telephony upon request. If the person is outside the US during the initial proceeding, counsel may be appointed by the judge. For initial proceedings under section 3261(a), a Federal magistrate judge may appoint qualified military counsel for the hearing. Qualified military counsel is a judge advocate certified by the Judge Advocate General and meets specific educational requirements. "Sec. 3266. Regulations" - This section pertains to regulations related to the appointment of qualified military counsel for initial proceedings under section 3261(a). The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of State and the Attorney General, will establish regulations for the apprehension, detention, delivery, and removal of individuals under this chapter. These regulations must be consistent across the Department of Defense. Additionally, regulations will require notice to be given to non-U.S. nationals employed by or accompanying the Armed Forces outside the U.S. about potential U.S. criminal jurisdiction under this chapter. Failure to provide notice as required will not invalidate the regulations. The regulations established by the Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of State and the Attorney General, must not undermine the jurisdiction of U.S. courts or serve as a defense in legal proceedings under this chapter. Any regulations or amendments must be submitted to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees at least 90 days before taking effect. "Sec. 3267. Definitions" - This section provides definitions for terms used in the regulations. The term 'employed by the Armed Forces outside the United States' refers to individuals working for the Department of Defense or its contractors outside the US who are not nationals or residents of the host nation. 'Accompanying the Armed Forces outside the United States' includes dependents of military members or Department of Defense civilian employees. The term 'employed by the Armed Forces outside the United States' includes Department of Defense employees, contractors, and subcontractors residing outside the US who are not host nation nationals. The term 'Armed Forces' refers to armed forces as defined in title 10. (b) Clerical Amendment.--The table of chapters for part II of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new item after chapter 211. Military extraterritorial jurisdiction is discussed in chapter 212, with references to the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
